items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as river levels peaked overnight and are now falling.  No further flooding is currently expected in this area. Please see the gov.uk website for a 5 day flood forecast and river levels.
The flood alert for the river Rye catchment has now been removed as levels have fallen below levels of concern.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise is forecast.      
We continue to monitor the situation.
The flood alert for the river Esk catchment has now been removed as levels have fallen below levels of concern.

River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland will continue throughout Wednesday 01/12/2021. Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Seven and its tributaries, including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck and Catter Beck. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday 02/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 01/12/2021 and tomorrow, Thursday 02/12/2021.  Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Riccal and it's tributaries including Bonfield Gill, Bogmire Gill, Ellerker Beck, Keld Spring Beck and Walmouth Beck. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels will continue to remain high during Wednesday 01/12/21. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We expect river levels to start to fall on Thursday 02/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt, and additional rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible on Wednesday 01/12/21 and we expect river levels to remain high into the early hours on Thursday 02/12/21. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We plan to operate the Foss Barrier on Wednesday 01/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible on Wednesday 01/12/21 and we expect river levels to remain high into the early hours of Thursday 02/12/21, around the Naburn area. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent has been issued. River levels have risen as a result of rainfall and snowmelt over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 01/12/2021. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.70mAOD at 23:45 on 01/12/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 27 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 02/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 20:45pm and 22:45pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front, may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon, may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.74mAODN at 21:45pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.60m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 20:15pm and 22:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.59mAODN at 21:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.77m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 20:15pm and 22:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.59mAODN at 21:15pm tonight, Wednesday 1st December 2021, which is 0.77m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 5:45am to 7:45am tomorrow, Thursday 2 December 2021.  We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft, as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.79mAODN at 6:45am, on Thursday 2nd December 2021, which is 0.75m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.   Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further warnings as required. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 2nd December 2021.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The flood gates at Rothbury are now open. 
The forecast continues to be unsettled over the next few days, however river levels are forecast to remain steady. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
